Idiom (Akan): Nsuo nni nan, nanso ɛkɔ baabiara.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Someone or something that finds its way everywhere; describes pervasive influence or widespread presence.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Obi anaa ade bi bɛda hɔ baabiara.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Drawn from Akan traditional wisdom; reflects the belief that truth and presence cannot be hidden.
First Example Sentence: Wɔka sɛ nsuo nni nan, nanso ɛkɔ baabiara, efisɛ nokware no betumi akɔ baabiara.
Second Example Sentence: Ɔman no din te sɛ nsuo, ɛkɔ baabiara wɔ abɔnten.
Third Example Sentence: Sɛ wopɛ sɛ wuhu nea ɛrekɔ so a, kae sɛ nsuo nni nan.

Idiom (Akan): Abofra bo a ɔnkyerɛ no yɛ ne tirim nanso ɔde to ɔhene ho.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A stubborn child learns lessons the hard way.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Obiara bɛsua adeɛ wɔ ne bere mu.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Akan traditional proverb emphasizing experiential learning and discipline.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Akan): à.bó.frá bó á ɔ̀ɲ́.t͡ɕé.rɛ́ nó yɛ́ nɛ́ tí.rím ná.n.sɔ ɔ́.dé tó ɔ́.hé.né hó
First Example Sentence: Ɔbarima no yɛɛ basabasa, na wopɛ sɛ ɔte ase a, abofra bo a ɔnkyerɛ no yɛ ne tirim.
Second Example Sentence: Ɛyɛ sɛ ɔte nkae no, efisɛ ɔde to ɔhene ho.
Third Example Sentence: Sɛ ɔyɛɛ no yiye a, ɔrenkae sɛnea ɔsuaeɛ no.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: If you don’t make an effort, you will not progress.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Sɛ woannye wo ho adwuma a, wo renkɔ anim.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common Akan saying linked to diligence and effort.
First Example Sentence: Ɔka kyerɛɛ no sɛ anoma antu a, ɔbɛda, enti ɔsɔreɛ kɔɔ sukuu.
Second Example Sentence: Sɛ wopɛ nkɔsoɔ a, kae sɛ anoma antu a, ɔbɛda.
Third Example Sentence: Ɔnni nsa ho adwuma, enti ɔda daa.

Idiom (Akan): Wɔse, sika yɛ aboa a ɔte fie a ɔkyere ne ho.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Money is useless when not spent; wealth should be circulated.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Sika nni mfaso sɛ wode nsɛe.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional Akan proverb commenting on the futility of hoarding wealth.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Akan): sí.ká yɛ́ à.bó.á á ɔ́.té fí.ɛ́ á ɔ́.ɕé.rɛ́ né hó
First Example Sentence: Ɔda sika no so daa, na wɔka sɛ sika yɛ aboa a ɔte fie a ɔkyere ne ho.
Second Example Sentence: Ɛnfa mfaso sɛ sika da fam, ɛsɛ sɛ yɛde di dwuma.
Third Example Sentence: Obi a ɔkyere ne ho sika mu rentumi nyɛ ade.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: One’s offspring will resemble them or follow their path.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: An old Akan proverb linking inheritance and character resemblance.
First Example Sentence: Ɔbɔ ne ho bo sɛnea ne papa no yɛ, kae sɛ ɔkɔtɔ nwo anomaa.
Second Example Sentence: Ɔbaa no yɛ sɛ ne maame pɛpɛɛpɛ; ampa, ɔkɔtɔ nwo anomaa.
Third Example Sentence: Sɛnea ɔyɛ no, ɛkyerɛ sɛ ne busuani nni nsakraeɛ.

Idiom (Akan): Sei no ho yɛ den sɛ aboa kɔtɔ mu.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: The matter is very difficult or complicated.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Metaphor from rural Akan hunting culture, comparing difficulty to a crab’s hard shell.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Akan): sèí nó hó yɛ́ dén sɛ à.bó.á kɔ́.tɔ́ mú
First Example Sentence: Asɛm a wɔde brɛ me no yɛ den sɛ aboa kɔtɔ mu.
Second Example Sentence: Ɛyɛ den paa sɛ yɛbɛtumi ayi nea ɛkɔ so no.
Third Example Sentence: Ɔkae sɛ, 'sei no ho yɛ den sɛ aboa kɔtɔ mu' na obiara tee aseɛ.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Children should not challenge authority or elders.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Abofra nni tumi sɛ ɔbɛka asɛm tia mpanyin.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from Akan chieftaincy systems emphasizing respect for hierarchy.
First Example Sentence: Ɛnyɛ ne dea sɛ ɔka, abofra na ɔmmɔ ɔhene da.
Second Example Sentence: Ɔsuae sɛ, sɛ ɔyɛ abofra a, ɔmmɔ ɔhene da.
Third Example Sentence: Wɔkae no wɔ abusuakuo no mu sɛnea yɛde yɛ nkɔmmɔ.

Idiom (Akan): Sɛ wokɔ ɔhene fie a, fa wo ho yɛ dɛ.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Behave appropriately in places of authority or respect.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Sɛ wopɛ sɛ wokɔ baabi a, yɛ sɛnea ɛfata.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Proverb from Akan royal customs emphasizing decorum and self-control.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Akan): sɛ̀ wɔ́.kɔ́ ɔ́.hé.né fí.ɛ́ á fá wɔ́.hó yɛ́ dé
First Example Sentence: Ɔka kyerɛɛ no sɛ, sɛ wokɔ ɔhene fie a, fa wo ho yɛ dɛ.
Second Example Sentence: Ɔkyerɛɛ ne ba sɛ nkɔɔ yɛ nkɔyɛ, fa wo ho yɛ dɛ.

Idiom (Akan): Abɔfra a ɔmpɛ sɛ ne nan ho yɛ fi no, ɔyɛ aboa.
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Complex comparative structure with conditional nuance
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A person unwilling to improve or change is foolish.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Sɛ obi mpɛ nkɔsoɔ a, ɔyɛ gyimii.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Used in Akan oral traditions to criticize laziness and stagnation.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Akan): à.bó.frá á ɔ́m.pɛ́ sɛ́ né nán hó yɛ́ fí nó ɔ́.yɛ́ à.bó.á
First Example Sentence: Wɔkaa no wɔ asafo no mu sɛ abɔfra a ɔmpɛ sɛ ne nan ho yɛ fi no, ɔyɛ aboa.
Second Example Sentence: Ɔkyerɛɛ no sɛ ɔnsakra ne tirim, na ɔmmɛyɛ yie.
Third Example Sentence: Ɛyɛ kasakoa a Akanfoɔ de kyere wɔn a wɔmfa wɔn ho nsi.

Idiom (Akan): Sɛ aboa bi wu a, n’akofoɔ yɛ no da.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: When one fails, those connected to them suffer as well.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Sɛ obi yɛ basaa a, ɛka ne nnamfoɔ.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rooted in communal Akan philosophy emphasizing interdependence.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Akan): sɛ̀ à.bó.á bí wʊ́ á nà à.kó.fó ɔ́ yɛ́ nó dá
First Example Sentence: Wɔka sɛ sɛ aboa bi wu a, n’akofoɔ yɛ no da, enti yɛn nyinaa bɛhia.
Second Example Sentence: Ɔman no te sɛ aboa no akofoɔ, sɛ ɔhene di nkogu a, ɛka wɔn nyinaa.
Third Example Sentence: Sɛ wo nua yɛ asɛm bɔne a, ɛka wo nso.
